info.name: PaywithAccount API
info.description: OnePipe supports _direct-from-account_ payments. This enables money to be _pulled_ from customer bank accounts into your business account. Either as a one-time transaction, or on a recurring basis. We built [paywithaccount.com](https://paywithaccount.com) as a use case on OnePipe to drive this specific scenario. \[ [explainer video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-VND79PZuXQ) | [product website ](https://www.paywithtransfer.com/developers/) | [sandbox postman collection](https://paywithaccount.com/sandbox) \] ## Customers can link their bank accounts to your platform ## You can take payments from linked accounts 1. Request a customer's consent to link their account to your service 2. Wait a bit for their consent and bank approval to be processed 3. You'd get a notification on your webhook once #2 has happened 4. Then, you can request payments off those accounts at any time 5. You can also call the [scheduler ](#f84d06cd-9c00-4006-bbd7-3ef449346b95) at any time to setup recurring payments 6. Listen for notifications informing you of successful or failed transactions 7. Fulfil the customer's service request based on #6 --- #### Take a look at what's possible > Want to see an ideal embedded payments integration that combines virtual accounts with 1-click direct-from-account payments? Play with [this demo](http://demo.paywithaccount.com) and see what happens after you register. You can embed an experience just like that --- > **To get started:** [Sign up, ](https://app.paywithaccount.com/sign-up) and after compliance checks and approval, request API access. You can also be provided with a prepared postman collection that you can just import and use if you don't want to construct your collection yourself using the information provided. # Getting started Here are the preliminary steps before you can use PaywithAccount via APIs 1. Sign up on PaywithAccount \[[guide](https://paywithaccount.com/guide/?q=How%20to%20request%20API%20access)\] 2. Request API access \[[guide](https://paywithaccount.com/guide/?q=How%20to%20request%20API%20access)\] 3. Once approved, you will receive 2 emails: 1. That contains the postman collection 2. Another with a link to set up your password. After setting your password, log in and retrieve your credentials. # **General Information** All requests to the API are made through a single base URL: ``` https://api.onepipe.io ``` There are no separate URLs for sandbox and production. Instead, the environment is controlled by the **`mock_mode`** field in the request payload. ### Mock mode - **`mock_mode = inspect`** **→** Sandbox Mode - Requests are processed in test mode. - You receive mock responses that simulate the expected behavior of the endpoint. - Recommended for development and early-stage integration testing. - **`mock_mode = live`** **→** Production Mode - Requests are processed in live mode. - You receive real-time responses based on actual inputs and live transaction flows. - Use this mode only after successful sandbox testing. ## Access to Live Mode During Integration During the integration phase, you will be provided with limited access to the `mock_mode = live` setting. - This allows you to preview real-time responses and perform end-to-end testing of your workflows. - Access is controlled and monitored to ensure stability and compliance. - Full unrestricted access to production (`mockmode = live`) is granted only after your integration is fully tested and approved. # Headers Every API call must include specific headers for authentication, security, and proper request handling. Below is a breakdown of the required headers and their purposes: 1. **Content-Type** ``` Content-Type: application/json ``` - Informs the server that the body of the request is in JSON format - Required for all request **2\. Authorization** ``` Authorization: Bearer {api_key} ``` - This header contains the API key assign to you - It authenticates the request and confirms that the call is made by an authorized client - Format: `Bearer {{your_api_key}}` **`3.`** **Signature** ``` Signature: {{MD5Hash(request_ref;client_secret)}} ``` - Ensures integrity and security of the request. - Generated using an MD5 hash function - To compute the signature: - Concatenate the `request_ref` (a unique reference for every API call) and your `client_secret` separated by a semi colon `(;)`. - Apply the MD5 hashing function to the concatenated string. - This hashed value is then sent as the `Signature` header. - Purpose: - To verify that the request originates from a trusted source. - Serves as a second layer of security by “signing” the request. **Example Header format** Your complete header for evey single call will look like ``` Content-Type:application/json Authorization:Bearer {{api_key}} Signature:{{MD5Hash(request_ref;client_secret)}} ``` ## Notes - **request_ref**: A unique identifier generated for every API call. No two requests should have the same reference. - The server validates the `Signature` by regenerating the hash internally and comparing it with the one provided. - If the values do not match, the request will be rejected. # Request Payload Structure Every API request uses a common payload structure. This ensures consistency across services and reduces integration effort. The payload is divided into standard objects, each serving a specific purpose. ##### **Top Level Fields** | **Field** | **Type** | **Requirement** | **Description** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | request_ref | String | Yes | Unique reference ID for this API call. Must be unique for every request. | | request_type | String | Yes | Defines the type of request. For mandate checks, use Get Accounts Max. | | auth | Object | Yes | Contains authentication information (provider, type, secure value). | | transaction | Object | Yes | Holds transaction-specific details like reference, amount, customer info. | ##### Auth Object | **Field** | **Type** | **Requirement** | **Descriptional** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | type | String/null | No | Authentication type other service. For mandate check,get_bank, may be null. | | secure | String/null | No | Encrypted authentication value. May be null if not applicable. | | auth_provider | String | Yes | Identifies the authentication provider. Use `PaywithAccount`. | #### **Type** This defines the authentication type and varies depending on the service being called. - For get banks service → the value is `null`. - For mandate creation → the value is `"bank.account"`, because a mandate is being placed on a specific account. #### **Secure** If type has a value, then secure must also have a value. - The value is encrypted using TripleDES with your secret key as the encryption key. ``` TripleDES.encrypt("{account_number};{cbn_bankcode}", secretKey) ``` #### **The Auth Object** Using the formula, the full object looks like this: ``` "type": "bank.account", "secure": TripleDES.encrypt("{account_number};{cbn_bankcode}", secretKey), "auth_provider": "paywithaccount" ``` #### Sample encryption in Java ``` MessageDigest md = MessageDigest.getInstance("md5"); byte[] digestOfPassword = md.digest(key.getBytes("UTF-16LE")); byte[] keyBytes = Arrays.copyOf(digestOfPassword, 24); for (int j = 0, k = 16; j < 8;) { keyBytes[k++] = keyBytes[j++]; } SecretKey secretKey = new SecretKeySpec(keyBytes, 0, 24, "DESede"); IvParameterSpec iv = new IvParameterSpec(new byte[8]); Cipher cipher = Cipher.getInstance("DESede/CBC/PKCS5Padding"); cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, secretKey, iv); byte[] plainTextBytes = toBeEncrypted.getBytes("UTF-16LE"); byte[] cipherText = cipher.doFinal(plainTextBytes); String output = new String(Base64.encodeBase64(cipherText)); return output; ``` #### Sample encryption in C-Sharp ``` string encryptedText = ""; MD5 md5 = new MD5CryptoServiceProvider(); TripleDES des = new TripleDESCryptoServiceProvider(); des.KeySize = 128; des.Mode = CipherMode.CBC; des.Padding = PaddingMode.PKCS7; byte[] md5Bytes = md5.ComputeHash(Encoding.Unicode.GetBytes(key)); byte[] ivBytes = new byte[8]; des.Key = md5Bytes; des.IV = ivBytes; byte[] clearBytes = Encoding.Unicode.GetBytes(TextToEncrypt); ICryptoTransform ct = des.CreateEncryptor(); using (MemoryStream ms = new MemoryStream()) { using (CryptoStream cs = new CryptoStream(ms, des.CreateEncryptor(), CryptoStreamMode.Write)) { cs.Write(clearBytes, 0, clearBytes.Length); cs.Close(); } encryptedText = Convert.ToBase64String(ms.ToArray()); } return encryptedText; ``` #### Sample encryption in PHP ``` function EncryptV2($encryption_key,$data) { $source = mb_convert_encoding($encryption_key, 'UTF-16LE', 'UTF-8'); $key = md5($source, true); $key .= substr($key, 0, 8); // a 128 bit (16 byte) key // append the first 8 bytes onto the end //Pad for PKCS7 $block = mcrypt_get_block_size('tripledes', 'cbc'); $len = strlen($data); $padding = $block - ($len % $block); $data .= str_repeat(chr($padding),$padding); $iv = "\0\0\0\0\0\0\0\0"; $encData = mcrypt_encrypt('tripledes', $key, $data, 'cbc',$iv); echo base64_encode($encData); } ``` #### Sample encryption in Node.js ``` const crypto = require('crypto'); function encrypt(sharedKey, plainText) { const bufferedKey = Buffer.from(sharedKey, 'utf16le'); const key = crypto.createHash('md5').update(bufferedKey).digest(); const newKey = Buffer.concat([key, key.slice(0, 8)]); const IV = Buffer.alloc(8, '\0'); const cipher = crypto.createCipheriv('des-ede3-cbc', newKey, IV).setAutoPadding(true); return cipher.update(plainText, 'utf8', 'base64') + cipher.final('base64'); } ``` #### Transaction Object | **Field** | **Type** | **Requirement** | **Description** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | mock_mode | String | Yes | Defines the simulation mode for testing. Example: "Inspect" | | transaction_ref | String | Yes | Unique reference for this transaction. Must be unique for each request. | | transaction_description | String | Yes | Short description of the transaction purpose. Example: "Check active mandates" | | transaction_ref_parent | String/Null | No | Optional reference to a parent transaction (for nested or linked transactions). | | amount | Number | Yes | Amount involved in the transaction. Use 0 if the transaction does not involve payment. | | customer | Object | Yes | Contains customer-specific information (see below). | | meta | Object | No | Optional metadata related to the transaction (e.g., biller code, category). | | details | Object | No | Additional transaction-specific details; can be empty if not applicable. | **Customer Object** The `customer` object stores information to uniquely identify and contact the customer. **Fields are optional depending on the service being called**. If not required, they can be left as empty strings (`""`) | **Field** | **Type** | **Requirement** | **Description** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | customer_ref | String | Yes | Unique customer identifier. Always advised to use the 13-digit phone number starting with 234. Example: 2348022222222 | | firstname | String | No | Customer first name. Can be left as "" if not required by the service | | surname | String | No | Customer last name. Can be left as "" if not required | | email | String | No | Customer email address. Can be left as "" if not required | | mobile_no | String | No | Customer mobile phone number. Can be left as "" if not required | #### Meta Object The `meta` object is **optional** and can contain extra contextual information for the transaction depending on the service. | **Field** | **Type** | **Requirement** | **Description** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | biller_code | String | No | Code identifying the biller or service provider. Example: "000019" | **Details Object** - The `details` object can contain additional information relevant to the transaction. - It can be empty (`{}`) if no extra details are needed. `Doc W.I.P.`

request.description:
**Check ACtive Mandate (Get Account Max)**

This service checks whether a customer has any **active mandates** linked to their `customer_ref`.

- The `customer_ref` is the key identifier used for lookup.
    
- It is always advised to be the customer’s **13-digit phone number** starting with `234` (e.g., `2348022221412`).
    
- Other customer fields (`firstname`, `surname`, `email`, `mobile_no`) are optional for this service. They may be provided, but can also be left as empty strings (`""`).
    
- Since this service does not involve payments, the `amount` field is set to `0`.

response.name: Successful

request.description:
**Send Invoice PWT**

The Send Invoice service generates a virtual account for a single payment collection. This account can then be shared with the customer for settlement.

- The `type` and `secure` fields in the `auth` object are set to **null** since this service allows transfers from any bank.
    
- Other customer fields (`firstname`, `surname`) are optional for this service. They may be provided, but can also be left as empty strings (`""`)
    
- The `meta.type` field must be `"single_payment"`, which indicates this is a one-time virtual account.
    
- An `expires_in` value must be specified (in minutes) to determine how long the virtual account remains active.
    
- The `skip_messaging` field is a boolean that controls whether the system sends payment details to the customer via WhatsApp, email, or SMS:
    
    - `false` → Notifications will be sent.
        
    - `true` → No notifications will be sent.

item.name: 3. Request payment - single - PWT to create mandate

request.description:
**Send Invoice PWA**

  
This service is used when you want to collect a single payment directly from a specific customer bank accoun**t**. , this flow is restricted: the payment must come from the exact account provided in the `secure` field.

- **Auth Object**
    
    - `type` → `"bank.account"` because you are binding this payment to a specific bank account.
        
    - `secure` → contains the **encrypted account details** (e.g., `{account_number};{cbn_bankcode}` encrypted with TripleDES and your secret key).
        
    - `auth_provider` → `"PaywithAccount"`.
        
- Why `type` and `secure` have values here
    
    - In this service, the customer is required to pay only from the specified account.
        
    - For example, if the secure field holds a Zenith Bank account, then the transfer must originate from that Zenith account.
        
    - If the customer pays from another account, the transaction will be disputed because it violates the mandate of this request.
        
- **Transaction Object**
    
    - `amount` → mandatory, since this is a single payment collection.
        
    - `firstname` and `surname` → optional; they can be provided or left as empty strings.
        
    - `customer_ref` → must still be the 13-digit phone number starting with `234`.
        
- Meta Object
    
    - An `expires_in` value must be specified (in minutes) to determine how long the virtual account remains active.
        
    - The `skip_messaging` field is a boolean that controls whether the system sends payment details to the customer via WhatsApp, email, or SMS:
        
        - `false` → Notifications will be sent.
            
        - `true` → No notifications will be sent.

request.description:
**Collect (Direct Debit)**

This service is used to initiate a single payment debit from a customer’s bank account. this method requires the payer’s account details to be explicitly provided.  
For this request to succeed, the customer must already have an active mandate on their account. In other words, their account must have been tokenized beforehand. Without a valid mandate, the debit attempt will fail.

- **Auth Object**
    
    - **type**: `"bank.account"` → specifies that the debit is being done on a bank account.
        
    - **secure**: contains the encrypted token (linked to the customer’s account) that was created when the mandate was set up. This token is what authorizes the debit.
        
    - **auth_provider**: `"PaywithAccount"`.
        
- **Amount**: the amount to be debited from the customer’s account.
    
    - The value must be provided in kobo (e.g., 1560000 = ₦15,600).
        
- **Meta Object**
    
    - **biller_code** → identifies the biller on whose behalf the debit is being made.
        
        - This field is mandatory and must match the biller’s registered code.
            

#### **Notes**

- This request is not an instruction for the customer to initiate payment. Instead, the debit is initiated directly on the customer’s tokenized account.
    
- The secure field is critical, as it ensures the debit is tied to the correct customer mandate.

request.description:
**Send Invoice (Installment Payment)**

#### **Auth Object**

- **type**: `"bank.account"` → specifies that the payment is tied to a specific customer bank account.
    
- **secure**: contains the encrypted account details (e.g., `{account_number};{cbn_bankcode}` encrypted with TripleDES and your secret key)
    
- **auth_provider**: `"PaywithAccount"`.
    

**Transaction Object**

- **amount**: the total amount to be collected across the instalments. Must be in **kobo** (e.g., `30000` = ₦300).
    
- **transaction_ref:** unique reference for this collection.
    
- **transaction_desc:** description of the payment (free text).
    
- **customer_ref:** the 13-digit customer phone number starting with `234`.
    
- **firstname, surname, email, mobile_no** → optional; they can be populated or left as empty strings.
    

#### **Meta Object**

- **type:** `"instalment"` → instructs the system this is an instalment-based payment.
    
- **down_payment:** upfront amount to be collected immediately (in kobo).
    
- **repeat_frequency:** how often subsequent payments occur (`daily`, `weekly`, `monthly`).
    
- **repeat_start_date:** the date and time when instalment deductions begin. Must follow the format: `yyyy-MM-dd-hh-mm-ss`.
    
- **number_of_payments:** total number of instalment payments (excluding the down payment).
    
- **biller_code:** mandatory; identifies the biller on whose behalf the collection is being made.
    

#### **How the Payment Flow Works**

1. When this request is made, the API responds with a virtual account where the customer must pay the down payment.
    
2. The transfer for the down payment must come from the same bank account linked in the `secure` field. If payment is made from another account, it will be disputed.
    
3. Once the down payment is settled, all subsequent instalments are debited automatically from the customer’s mandate-linked account, based on the schedule (`repeat_frequency` and `repeat_start_date`).

request.description:
**Send Invoice (subscription payment)**

- **type**: `"bank.account"` → ties the subscription to a specific customer bank account.
    
- **secure**: contains the encrypted account details (e.g., `{account_number};{cbn_bankcode}` encrypted with TripleDES and your secret key)
    
- **auth_provider**: `"PaywithAccount"`.
    

#### **Transaction Object**

- **amount:** the recurring amount to be debited at each cycle. Must be in **kobo** (e.g., `10500` = ₦105).
    
- **transaction_ref:** unique reference for this subscription request.
    
- **transaction_desc:** description of the subscription (free text).
    
- **customer_ref:** must always be the 13-digit phone number starting with `234`.
    
- **firstname, surname, email, mobile_no:** optional; they can be populated or left as empty strings.
    

#### **Meta Object**

Defines the subscription plan:

- **type:** `"subscription"` indicates this request is setting up a recurring debit.
    
- **repeat_frequency:** how often the debit should occur (`daily`, `weekly`, `monthly`).
    
- **repeat_start_date:** the date and time when the subscription debits should begin. Format: `yyyy-MM-dd-hh-mm-ss`.
    
- **repeat_end_date:** the date and time when the subscription should automatically stop. Format: `yyyy-MM-dd-hh-mm-ss`.
    
- **biller_code:** mandatory; identifies the biller on whose behalf the subscription is being set up.
    

**Subscription Flow**

1. **Request Initiation**
    
    - When you send a subscription request, the response you receive depends on the **a**ctivation method agreed with the business (either first payment or transfer).
        
    - This first action serves as customer consent to allow recurring debits on their account.
        
2. **First Payment (Virtual Account Route)**
    
    - Every time a new subscription is initiated, a virtual account is generated.
        
    - The customer is required to make a transfer to this account for the first billing cycle (e.g., paying for the first month of a subscription).
        
    - Once this payment is received, the subscription becomes active.
        
    - Subsequent debits will then occur automatically from the customer’s linked account, according to the **s**tart date, end date, and repeat frequency defined in the request.
        
3. **Transfer (Activation URL Route)**
    
    - Alternatively, the response will include an **`activation_url`**.
        
    - You can either:
        
        - Display the content of the URL directly in your own platform (skipping external messaging), **or**
            
        - Send the URL to the customer via SMS, WhatsApp, or any other channel.
            
    - The customer follows the instructions and gives consent by sending a transfer (via NIBSS).
        
    - Once the transfer is completed and confirmed, the subscription is activated.
        
    - Future recurring debits then proceed automatically from the authorized account.
        
4. **Subsequent Debits**
    
    - After activation (via first payment or transfer), the system handles debits automatically:
        
        - Based on the `repeat_frequency` (daily, weekly, monthly, etc.).
            
        - Continuing until the `repeat_end_date` or when the subscription is cancelled.

request.description:
**Check Active Mandate On An Account(Get Account Max)**

This service allows you to verify if a customer already has an active mandate on a specific account. The account details are the same ones encrypted into the `secure` field of the auth object.

- `type`: `"bank.account"` → indicates the mandate check is being done against a bank account.
    
- `secure`: encrypted account details (token or account identifier tied to mandate).
    
- `auth_provider`: `"PaywithAccount"`.
    
- `amount`: `0` → since this is only a mandate verification, no debit occurs.

request.description:
**Create Mandate**

The Create Mandate endpoint is used to tokenize a customer’s account so you can directly debit it.

This is an account-to-account mandate managed by the bank. Once a mandate is successfully created, it takes up to 24 hours to become active.

StartFragment

#### **Auth Object**

- `type`: `"bank.account"` → specifies that the mandate is being set up on a bank account.
    
- `secure`: contains the encrypted account details
    
- `auth_provider`: `"PaywithAccount"`.
    

#### **Transaction Object**

- `transaction_desc`: `"Creating a mandate"`.
    
- `amount`: `0` → no funds are moved during mandate creation.
    
- `customer`:
    
    - `customer_ref`: must be the customer’s 13-digit phone number (e.g., `2348022221412`).
        
    - `firstname`, `surname`, `email`, `mobile_no`: should be filled in.
        

#### **Meta Object**

- `amount`: Maximum single debit limit allowed on the customer’s account for this mandate.
    
- `skip_consent`:
    
    - `false`
        
- `bvn`: Customer’s BVN encrypted with TripleDES.
    
- `biller_code`: Your biller code.
    
- `customer_consent`: This will be communicated based on you integration settings
    

### **Verification Process (Under the Hood)**

When this request is made, the system verifies:

1. Account details (from `secure`).
    
2. BVN (must match account details).
    
3. Phone number (`customer_ref`) against the primary number linked to the customer’s NIN.
    
4. **Name matching**:
    
    - First, the system checks if the account name matches the BVN name → contributes 50% score.
        
    - Then it cross-checks the phone number linked to NIN .
        
    - The minimum required score is **50%** to create a mandate.If the score falls below 50%, the mandate creation request fails with an error.
        

## **Response**

The response contains an **activation URL**. You can:

- Display the content of the URL directly on your platform, or
    
- Let PaywithAccount deliver it via WhatsApp, Email, or SMS (depending on your integration settings).
    

If skip messaging is enabled, you are responsible for presenting the URL to the customer.

---

## **Consent Flow (Transfer Activation Method)**

1. **Accept Account for Tokenization**
    
    - The customer sees the account details that will be tokenized.
        
    - Clicking Continue confirms their acceptance.
        
2. **Create / Input PIN**
    
    - The customer sets up a PIN, which will later be used to authorize mandate operations or consent renewals once the mandate expires.
        
3. **Transfer to NIBSS Virtual Account**
    
    - A NIBSS-controlled virtual account is displayed.
        
    - The customer must transfer funds from the same account being tokenized.
        
    - This transfer does not go to your business. Instead, it acts as a consent signal to NIBSS to confirm mandate creation.

request.description:
**Collect (Direct Debit)**

This service is used to initiate a single payment debit from a customer’s bank account. This method requires the payer’s account details to be provided explicitly.  
For this request to succeed, the customer must already have an active mandate on their account. In other words, their account had to be tokenized beforehand. Without a valid mandate, the debit attempt will fail.

- **Auth Object**
    
    - **type**: `"bank.account"` → specifies that the debit is being done on a bank account.
        
    - **secure**: contains the encrypted token (linked to the customer’s account) that was created when the mandate was set up. This token is what authorizes the debit.
        
    - **auth_provider**: `"PaywithAccount"`.
        
- **Amount**: the amount to be debited from the customer’s account.
    
    - The value must be provided in kobo (e.g., 1560000 = ₦15,600).
        
- **Meta Object**
    
    - **biller_code** → identifies the biller on whose behalf the debit is being made.
        
        - This field is mandatory and must match the biller’s registered code.
            

#### **Notes**

- This request is not an instruction for the customer to initiate payment. Instead, the debit is initiated directly on the customer’s tokenized account.
    
- The secure field is critical, as it ensures the debit is tied to the correct customer mandate.

request.description:
### Create Merchant Transaction

This endpoint allows you to initiate a transaction for creating a new merchant.

#### Request Body

- `request_ref` (string): A unique reference for the request.
    
- `request_type` (string): Indicates the type of request, in this case, "create merchant".
    
- `auth` (object): Authentication details including the provider and security settings.
    
    - `auth_provider` (string): The authentication provider, e.g., "PaywithAccount".
        
- `transaction` (object): Details of the transaction.
    
    - `mock_mode` (string): The mode for mocking the transaction, e.g., "Inspect".
        
    - `transaction_ref` (string): Reference for the transaction.
        
    - `transaction_desc` (string): Description of the transaction.
        
    - `amount` (number): The transaction amount.
        
    - `customer` (object): Details of the customer initiating the transaction.
        
        - `customer_ref` (string): Reference for the customer.
            
        - `firstname` (string): Customer's first name.
            
        - `surname` (string): Customer's surname.
            
        - `email` (string): Customer's email address.
            
        - `mobile_no` (string): Customer's mobile number.
            
    - `meta` (object): Additional meta information for the transaction.
        
        - `beta` (string): Indicates if beta features are enabled.
            
        - `biller_sector` (string): Sector of the biller.
            
        - `simple_payment` (string): Indicates if simple payment is enabled.
            
        - `webhook_url` (string): URL for webhook notifications.
            
        - `whatsapp_contact_name` (string): Name of the WhatsApp contact.
            
        - `whatsapp_contact_no` (string): WhatsApp contact number.
            
        - `business_short_name` (string): Short name of the business.
            
    - `details` (object): Details related to the business.
        
        - `business_name` (string): Name of the business.
            
        - `rc_number` (string): Registration number of the business.
            
        - `settlement_account_no` (string): Account number for settlement.
            
        - `settlement_bank_code` (string): Bank code for settlement.
            
        - `tax_id` (string): Tax identification number.
            
        - `address_line_1` (string): Address line 1 for the business.
            
        - `notification_phone` (string): Notification phone numbers.
            
        - `notification_email` (string): Notification email addresses.
            
- `options` (null): Additional options for the transaction.
    

#### Response

The response for this request is a JSON object with the following schema:

``` json
{
  "status": "",
  "message": "",
  "data": {
    "provider_response_code": "",
    "provider": "",
    "errors": null,
    "error": null,
    "provider_response": {
      "reference": 0,
      "account_number": "",
      "contract_code": null,
      "account_reference": "",
      "account_name": "",
      "currency_code": "",
      "customer_email": "",
      "bank_name": null,
      "bank_code": null,
      "account_type": null,
      "status": "",
      "created_on": "",
      "meta": {
        "biller_code": ""
      }
    },
    "client_info": {
      "name": null,
      "id": null,
      "bank_cbn_code": null,
      "bank_name": null,
      "console_url": null,
      "js_background_image": null,
      "css_url": null,
      "logo_url": null,
      "footer_text": null,
      "show_options_icon": true,
      "paginate": true,
      "paginate_count": 0,
      "options": null,
      "merchant": null,
      "colors": null,
      "meta": null
    }
  }
}

 ```

The response includes various fields such as `status`, `message`, `data`, `provider_response_code`, `provider`, and `client_info`.

request.description:
**Update Merchant**

The Update Merchant endpoint is used to update a merchant’s profile or configuration details.

- The `customer_ref` and `email` in the `customer` object are required.
    
- All other fields (both in `customer` and `meta`) are optional.
    
- Only include the fields you want to update in the request.
    

#### Transaction Object

- **transaction_desc:** `"Update merchant information"`.
    
- **amount:** always `0` (no funds are moved).
    

**Customer Object**

- `customer_ref` → required. Must be the merchant’s registered customer reference (13-digit phone number).
    
- `email` → required. Merchant’s email address.
    
- `firstname`, `surname`, `mobile_no` → optional;
    

**Meta Object**

Holds the fields you want to update. All fields are optional. Common examples:

- `status:` `"active"` or `"inactive"`.
    
- `biller_name:` Merchant’s display or business name.
    
- `webhook_url:` URL to receive transaction notifications.
    
- `notification_phone_number:` Comma-separated list of phone numbers for alerts.
    
- `notification_email:` Email address for notifications.

request.description:
**Lookup Merchant**

The Lookup Merchant endpoint is used to check if a merchant already exists on the platform.  
The unique identifier for lookup is passed in the `customer_ref` field, which is the biller code assigned to the merchant when created, or the email address, which is unique per merchant

#### Transaction Object

- **transaction_desc** → `"Get merchant details"`.
    
- **amount** → always `0` (no monetary value is involved).
    

**Customer Object**

- `customer_ref` → required (biller code or email).
    
- Other fields (`firstname`, `surname`, `email`, `mobile_no`) → optional and not used for this check (should be `null` or empty).

request.description:
With this, you can KYC a customer's bank verification number.This service unlike `LOOKUP BVN MIN`and `LOOKUP BVN MID` returns  maximum KYC information.


#### Sequence of calls
* Primary call: `/v2/transact`
* Provider responds with WaitingForOTP or PendingValidation (if required)
* Call `v2/transact/validate` to supply OTP if needed
* Provider responds with any of the completion codes `Successful` or `Failed`.
*Call `/transact/validate` to supply OTP if needed
* To query the status of a transaction, a call can be made to  `/v2/transact/query` endpoint.
* Depending on the provider, the app can call `v2/transact/reverse` to request a reversal


#### Interpreting the response
* Read the reponse
* Read the `provider_response` Object


#### Possible status values
* **Successful**: Success
* **[Anything else]**: Error. Read the errors object(s)

#### Breakdown of the details in the Request Object
| Element               | Description                                                                                     |
|-----------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| bvn           | Customer bvn to look up |
| otp_override           | **OPTIONAL** Defaults to `false`. If set to `true`, request will not be validated by OTP.
| dob| The date of birth to match in `yyyy-MM-dd` format   
| include_image| Defaults to `true`. Instructs the provider whether to include image of the BVN holder or not.                                                         |



#### Request body elements
| Element               | Description                                                                                     |
|-----------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| request_ref           | A unique reference for this specific API call. Must be uniquely generated for every single call |
| request_type           | Service identifier - `lookup_bvn_mid` |
| auth.type             | `bvn`.                                                         |
| auth.secure           | encrypted BVN|
| transaction.customer.customer_ref | Mobile number of the customer                                                                   |
| transaction.customer.firstname    | First name of the customer                                                                      |
| transaction.customer.surname      | Surname of the customer                                                                         |
| transaction.customer.email        | Email address of the customer                                                                   |
| transaction.customer.mobile_no    | Mobile number of the customer                                                                   |


#### Response body elements
| Element                     | Description                                                                     |
|-----------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| status                      | Standard response. **Successful** or anything else.                             |
| message                     | A message or description of the response                                        |
| data.provider               | The provider that was used to process the request                               |
| data.provider_response_code | Response code as determined by the underlying provider                          |
| data.provider_response| This object contains the actual response for the provider. It contains the `BVN` details                                             |




**NOTE**: Please see information on how to compute the `Signature` header [here](#authentication-headers)

response.name: Successful

request.description:
### Check Balance

The **Check Balance** endpoint is used to retrieve the current balance of a customer’s bank account.  
To perform this operation, the customer’s account must already have an **active mandate**.

#### Auth Object

- **type** → `"bank.account"` (specifies that the balance check is on a bank account).
    
- **secure** → contains the encrypted account details (`account_number;bank_code`) encrypted with TripleDES and your secret key.
    
- **auth_provider** → `"PaywithAccount"`.
    

---

#### Transaction Object

- **transaction_desc** → `"Get Account Balance"`.
    
- **amount** → always `0` (this is a non-monetary request).
    

**Customer Object**

- **customer_ref** → must be the customer’s 13-digit phone number (e.g., `2348022221412`).
    
- **firstname**, **surname**, **email**, **mobile_no** → optional, can be filled in or left empty.
    

**Meta Object**

- **biller_code** → your biller code (required).

request.description:
**Send SMS**

This request is used to send an SMS notification to a customer.  
It allows you (the biller/merchant) to proactively communicate important information, such as reminders, alerts, or confirmations, directly to the customer’s phone number.

### Details Object

The details object contains the actual content of the SMS notification to be sent to the customer.

- message_body: The main content of the SMS. This is the text the customer will receive (e.g., payment reminders, alerts, or notifications).
    
- message_title: The subject/title of the message. This helps categorize the notification (e.g., `"Subscription Debit Reminder"`).
    
- sender_id: The sender name/ID that appears as the source of the SMS when the customer receives it PWT

request.description:
**Send Whatsapp**

This request is used to send WhatsApp notifications to your customers. The customer_ref must contain the customer’s WhatsApp phone number (in the required format)

Details Object

The `details` object carries the full content of the WhatsApp message:

- template_id: The unique ID of the WhatsApp message template.
    
    - Templates must be created and approved on our WhatsApp provider platform before use.
        
    - Once approved, the ID will be shared with you.
        
- template_type: Defines the type of WhatsApp template, e.g., `"interactive"`.
    
- template_body: The body of the WhatsApp message, which can include variables (`{{1}}`, `{{2}}`, etc.).
    
    - These variables are placeholders that get replaced with actual values provided in `template_info`.
        
- template_info: A stringified JSON array mapping template variables
    

### Notes

- You cannot send arbitrary free-form WhatsApp messages.
    
- A pre-approved template must exist in our WhatsApp provider’s platform.
    
- Variables inside the template (`{{1}}`, `{{2}}`, etc.) make it flexible to personalize messages (like customer names, payment amounts, account numbers).

request.description:
**Send OTP**  
This is used to send a One-Time Password (OTP) to a customer. The OTP can be delivered via WhatsApp, SMS, or both, depending on the configuration in the `details` object.

### Auth Object

- **auth.type:** Determines where the phone number for OTP delivery is sourced from.
    
    - `null:` The OTP will be sent directly to the phone number provided in the `customer_ref`.
        
    - `"bank.account":` The `secure` object contains the encrypted account details. The system will find the phone number linked to that account and send the OTP there.
        
- **auth.secure:** Encrypted account details (required if `auth.type` = `"bank.account"`).
    
- **auth.auth_provider:** Always `"PaywithAccount"`.
    

### Details Object

The `details` object defines how the OTP will be delivered and its behavior:

- **type** → Channel of delivery:
    
    - `"sms_otp"` OTP sent via SMS.
        
    - `"whatsapp_otp"` OTP sent via WhatsApp.
        
    - `"both"` OTP sent to both channels simultaneously.
        
- **prompt_message** → A short contextual message sent along with the OTP to remind the customer what the OTP is for.Example: `"Processing N353 payment to Koko Below Inc."`
    
- **expiry_mins** → The validity period of the OTP in minutes. Example: `30` means the OTP expires after 30 minutes.

request.description:
**Validate OTP**  
This endpoint is used to validate the OTP that was previously sent to a customer using the Send OTP service  

**Auth Object**

- **auth.type:** Must be `"otp"`.
    
- **auth.secure:** The encrypted OTP value (the OTP received from the customer is encrypted before sending).
    
- **auth.auth_provider** → Always `"PaywithAccount"`.
    

### Details Object

- **reference:** The `transaction_ref` returned from the Send OTP API request. This links the validation attempt to the correct OTP request.
    
- **otp** → Always `null`. The actual OTP is not passed in plain text; instead, it is sent encrypted via the `secure` field in the `auth` object.

response.name: Validate OTP

request.description:
**Cancel Sub**  
This endpoint is used to cancel a subscription, installment, or mandate that has been placed on a customer’s account.

### Meta Object (payment_id)

- **payment_id** is the unique identifier required to perform the cancellation.
    
- **subscriptions** and **installments:** the `payment_id` is generated when the subscription or installment is created.
    
- **mandates:** the `subscription_id` returned in the create mandate response is passed into the `payment_id` field to deactivate the mandate.

response.name: Cancel Sub

request.description:
## Update Payment

The Update Payment service is used to pause or resume an existing subscription or installment.

### Meta Object

- **action:** specifies the operation you want to perform.
    
    - `"pause"`: temporarily halt the subscription or installment.
        
    - `"resume":` restart a previously paused subscription or installment.
        

### Details Object

- **payment_id** → the unique identifier of the subscription or installment you want to pause or resume.

response.name: Successful

request.description: With this service, the calling apps can do a transfer to a destination account number from a pre-configured account of the app. If authorisation details are required by a provider, apps will have to provide this. OnePipe will in turn forward to the provider’s dedicated implementation. This is a service that is useful for when a business wants to debit their own account and credit any destination account #### Sequence of calls Please be sure to have gone through... - [The headers](#the-headers) - [Main API operations](#the-main-operations-you-can-perform) - [Typical OnePipe requests](#what-requests-would-look-like) - [Typical OnePipe responses](#what-responses-would-look-like) - [Encryption of the secure element](#encryption-of-secure-element) Here's the call sequence specific to this service... 1. Call `/transact` 2. Provider responds with `WaitingForOTP` or `PendingValidation` if they require OTP verification 3. Call `/transact/validate` to supply OTP if needed 4. Provider responds with any of the completion codes `Successful` or `Failed`. 5. To query the status of a transaction, call `/transact/query` #### Interpreting the response - Read the response - Read the `provider_response` Object #### Possible status values - **Successful**: Success - **WaitingForOTP**: Display the `status.message` and collect the input from the user, then follow with a `/transact/validate` - **PendingValidation**: Display the `status.message` and collect the input from the user, then follow with a `/transact/validate` - **\[Anything else\]**: Error. Read the errors object(s) #### Request body elements | Field | Type | Requirement | Description | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | request_ref | string | compulsory | A unique reference for this API call | | request_type | string | compulsory | Set to `disburse` | | auth.type | string | compulsory | Set to be `null` | | auth.secure | string | compulsory | Set to be `null` | | auth.auth_provider | string | compulsory | The Provider against which you want to open the account. e.g. `SunTrust` | | auth.route_mode | string | compulsory | Set to `null` | | transaction.mock_mode | string | compulsory | Set to `inspect` (for test mode) or `live` (for live mode) | | transaction.transaction_ref | string | compulsory | A unique reference for the transaction | | transaction.transaction.desc | string | compulsory | A short description or narration | | transaction.transaction_ref_parent | string | optional | Can be set to `null`. But if you are repeating a prior transaction, you can set it to the `transaction_ref` of the former transaction to create a link for easy tracking. | | amount | int | compulsory | Set to amount in kobo to be processed | | transaction.customer.customer_ref | string | compulsory | A unique reference to identify this customer | | transaction.customer.firstname | string | compulsory | The firstname of the customer | | transaction.customer.surname | string | compulsory | The surname of the customer | | transaction.customer.email | string | compulsory | The email of the customer | | transaction.customer.mobile_no | string | compulsory | The mobile number of the customer | | transaction.details.destination_account | string | compulsory | The destination account number | | transaction.details.destination_bank_code | string | compulsory | The cbn bank code of the destination account number | #### Response body elements | Element | Description | | --- | --- | | status | Standard response. **Successful** or anything else. If the response is `WaitingForOTP` or `PendingValidation`, then display the `response.message`, collect the input from the user and follow with a `/transact/validate` API call. See [here](https://v2.docs.onepipe.io/?version=latest#b294a37e-e131-4fd3-931b-7868bec36e34). | | message | A message or description of the response | | data.provider | The provider that was used to process the request | | data.provider_response_code | Response code as determined by the underlying provider | | data.provider_response.reference | A reference from the provider for reconciliation purposes | | data.provider_response.destination_institution_code | NIP destination institution code | | data.provider_response.beneficiary_account_name | Beneficiary account name | | data.provider_response.beneficiary_account_number | Beneficiary account number | | data.provider_response.beneficiary_kyc_level | KYC level of beneficiary | | data.provider_response.originator_account_name | Sender account name | | data.provider_response.originator_account_number | KYC level of sender | | data.provider_response.originator_kyc_level | KYC level of sender | | data.provider_response.narration | Narration for the transaction | | data.provider_response.transaction_final_amount | Amount in `kobo` processed | | data.provider_response.payment_id | Transaction payment id | | data.provider_response.meta | A custom object that can hold any extra information the provider deems necessary in key vs value pairs. | #### List of providers For a list of providers that have published and implemented this service, please see here #### Common questions **Question**: Why do I need to specify `transaction.amount` when it's irrelevant here? **Answer**: OnePipe APIs all try to follow a common standard such that all services require the same exact payload. It's the values within the payload that will then vary, service by service. In this case, just set it to `0`. **Question**: What is the `meta` object in the request and response? **Answer**: Some providers at times require or return special fields not covered by the standard. If you know what some of these fields and their values are you can set them in the request `meta` object and read them from the response `meta` object. Typically though, `null` is perfectly fine in most cases.

request.description:
## Error Codes and Responses

| Code | Description | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 01 | Status unknown, please wait for settlement report | Occurs when transaction status is pending reconciliation |
| 03 | Invalid Sender | Invalid or unauthorized sender details |
| 05 | Do not honor | Transaction declined by issuer |
| 06 | Dormant Account | Account is inactive or restricted |
| 07 | Invalid Account | Invalid or non-existent account |
| 08 | Account Name Mismatch | Provided account name doesn’t match account number |
| 09 | Request processing in progress | Transaction is still being processed. |
| 12 | Invalid transaction | Transaction request not valid |
| 13 | Invalid Amount | Amount field is missing or invalid amount |
| 16 | Unknown Bank Code / Account lookup failed across all providers. Please try again later. | Invalid Bank code is sent |
| 18 | Wrong Method Call | API request used an invalid method |
| 21 | No action taken | Transaction could not be completed |
| 26 | Duplicate Record | Record already exists |
| 30 | Format error | Request payload/format is incorrect |
| 34 | Suspected fraud | Transaction flagged as fraudulent |
| 51 | Insufficient funds | Account has insufficient balance |
| 61 | Transfer limit exceeded | Sender’s transfer limit reached |
| 65 | Exceeds withdrawal frequency | Exceeds daily/periodic withdrawal limits |
| 68 | Response received too late | Timeout from destination |
| 71 | Empty Mandate Reference Number | Mandate reference is required but missing |
| 91 | Beneficiary Bank not available | Destination bank unavailable |
| 94 | Duplicate transaction | Same transaction already submitted in the span of 5min |
| 97 | Timeout waiting for response from destination | No timely response from destination bank/system |
